Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Morphing Minimally Invasive Surgery Instruments
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to make an impact on the minimally invasive surgical systems market, which is greater than $24 billion globally and is projected to grow to more than $40 billion by 2025. The desire for increasingly smaller incisions leads to a need for decreased size and increased functionality of laparoscopic surgical tools. The proposed instruments combine multiple laparoscopic surgical tools (e.g. graspers, endoscopes, and sealers) into a single instrument, reducing the time (and associated cost) of switching instruments. The technology enables multiple tools to be inserted into the surgical space through a single incision, which reduces the number of incisions, operating time, recovery time, and patient pain, while also improving cosmetics. This product could also decrease costs and make minimally invasive surgical systems more affordable for healthcare systems and patients worldwide.

This I-Corps project will evaluate creating next-generation minimally invasive surgery instruments by applying fundamental research in developable mechanisms. The proposed laparoscopic instruments take advantage of developable mechanisms' conforming and emerging ability and combine multiple surgical instruments into a single instrument, thereby decreasing the number of cannulas (surgical rods) needed to perform a surgery and the number of incisions required. Fewer incisions leads to faster recovery time, less pain, and improved cosmetics. By integrating multiple instruments into a single unit, this technology will also be able to decrease the number of units required for surgical procedures and thereby decrease instrument and sterilization costs. Developable mechanisms are a new class of kinematic mechanism that can conform to or be embedded in developable surfaces. Developable mechanisms are a simple, clean way to add functionality to existing shafts or tubes without adding material or increasing complexity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Developable mechanisms are a new class of kinematic mechanism that can conform to or be embedded in developable surfaces. Developable mechanisms are a simple, clean way to add functionality to existing shafts or tubes without adding material or increasing complexity. This project involves embedded developable mechanisms to create multifunctional laparoscopic surgical tools. Each device has a mechanism incorporated into the cannula, or shaft, of a traditional laparoscopic tool. These embedded mechanisms resemble a cylindrical shaft in their collapsed or conformed shape, but when deployed become a second surgical tool, operating either intermittently or in parallel with the traditional tool operating at the end of the cannula.

This project advances knowledge by demonstrating the untapped potential that developable mechanisms have in solving relevant and significant real-world problems. Developable mechanisms can be the basis for innovative and cost-effective devices that can accomplish sophisticated mechanical tasks. As the team conducted over 100 interviews with health-care professionals and observed surgical procedures firsthand, it became apparent that these mechanisms have significant potential in medical applications due to the prevalence of developable surfaces in medical devices. By focusing on commercial applications for instrumentation used in minimally invasive surgery, specific advantages of this technology are highlighted. In this field where cylindrical instruments are widely used in constrained spaces, simplification of procedure workflow is essential, and instrumentation costs are critical, developable mechanisms can add functionality, simplify workflow, and reduce costs by embedding and conforming extra mechanical components into the walls resulting in multifunctional tools.

Additionally, by understanding the requirements of medical devices such as biocompatibility, sanitation, and regulation, better design practices can be followed in future development. This information can also lead to improved material selection and manufacturing possibilities for medical device design.

Furthermore, this project demonstrates the added benefits of merging developable mechanism principles with compliant mechanisms to design products and components that have higher performance and more economical to manufacture.

Broader Impacts

This project demonstrates the potential of commercializing products with developable mechanism technology. Although the project highlighted applications for minimally invasive procedures, it also universally serves as an example of incorporating developable mechanisms into any cylindrical hardware, providing the framework to diversify mechanical design thinking and approaches when working with other developable surfaces in various industries. (e.g. a round wheel which can roll, but embedded developable mechanisms could emerge to allow the wheel to maneuver over obstacles.)

Traditionally, designers and engineers haven?t typically considered a mechanisms? ability to conform to and emerge from a surface. However, with a better understanding of developable mechanism principles and potential uses, product designers and engineers can reconsider how seemingly unusable real estate on a product?s surface can be transformed to accommodate extra functionality. This project serves that purpose by demonstrating how an instrument which has remained unchanged such as a trocar or laparoscope can increase functionality through these embedded mechanisms without altering its original form. 

These application discoveries not only have merit in numerous surgical and medical scenarios, but also in industries such as dentistry, space, plumbing, and downhole drilling. Experts in these fields all expressed interest in the capabilities of developable mechanisms to enter a highly constrained space in a compact state and then deploy to perform different functions. Developable mechanisms can be designed for these and many other potential applications. This project serves as an example of how existing technology in various industries can be rethought to incorporate developable mechanisms to achieve increased functionality. This is portrayed in the two examples seen in the attached images which have use similar developable mechanism configurations but applied in different industries and applications. The commercialization during it I-Corps program was focused on medical applications, however the lessons learned can be applied in a much broader scope.
